The spinless Falicov-Kimball model is a well-known model for studying charge-density-wave (CDW) phases. In this paper, we report a comprehensive study of the total electronic Raman scattering in the charge-density-wave phase of the spinless Falicov-Kimball model. Using advanced computational techniques, we calculate the Raman scattering spectra for various doping levels and interaction strengths. Our results reveal that the Raman scattering spectra exhibit distinct features that are sensitive to the CDW phase, providing valuable information about the electronic structure and the nature of the CDW phase transition. Our study sheds light on the potential of Raman scattering as a powerful probe for investigating charge-density-wave phases in correlated electron systems.

LONDON - Small businesses in the UK are facing rising costs that are threatening to undermine their profitability, a new survey has suggested.

The survey of more than 1,000 firms by the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB) found that rising costs, including wages, raw materials and energy, were the biggest challenge facing small businesses in the UK.

The FSB said that the rising costs were being driven by the weakening pound, which has made imports more expensive, and the national living wage, which has pushed up wages bills.

The survey also found that small firms were struggling to pass on the rising costs to customers, with many reporting that they were being forced to absorb the extra costs themselves.

Mike Cherry, national chairman of the FSB, said: "Rising costs are a major concern for small businesses, with many struggling to absorb the extra costs and maintain profitability.

"The weakening pound and national living wage are major factors driving up costs, and the government must take action to support small firms and help them to compete in the face of these challenges."

The survey comes as the government prepares to publish its autumn budget, which is expected to focus on measures to boost the economy and support small businesses.

A spokesman for SAIC declined to comment on the matter, while MG Rover was not immediately available for comment. The potential partnership has been seen as a way for MG Rover to gain access to China's rapidly growing car market, the world's largest, and to tap into SAIC's manufacturing and engineering expertise.

The ACNN (Adaptive Convolutional Neural Network) is a full resolution deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) designed for medical image segmentation. This paper presents the ACNN architecture, which adaptively learns spatial context and feature representations at multiple scales. The ACNN achieves state-of-the-art performance on several medical image segmentation tasks, including brain tumor segmentation and heart muscle segmentation. The ACNN's efficiency and accuracy make it a promising tool for clinical applications.

William Hague, the former British Foreign Secretary, has reportedly earned more than 600,000 in the year after he left office, according to a leaked document.

The document, which was obtained by the Daily Telegraph, shows that Mr Hague has earned the six-figure sum through a combination of speaking engagements, consultancy work and serving on the boards of several companies.

Mr Hague, who served as Foreign Secretary under the Conservative-led government from 2010 to 2014, has faced criticism over his lucrative post-politics career. However, he has argued that he is entitled to earn a living and that his work is in the national interest.

The leaked document, which is said to have been circulated among Conservative Party members, also reveals that Mr Hague's earnings have significantly increased since he left office in 2014. In the year after he stepped down, he earned 97,000 from his work as an MP, in addition to the 600,000 he received from outside sources.

The revelation comes at a time when there is growing concern over the lucrative opportunities available to former politicians, and the potential for conflicts of interest.

A spokesman for Mr Hague has declined to comment on the leaked document, but has previously defended his post-politics career, saying that he is "proud" of his work and that it is "in the national interest".

Authorities in the UK have arrested dozens of people in connection with an alleged identity fraud website. The site, which has not been named, is said to have allowed users to purchase stolen personal information, including bank account details and passport numbers.

The investigation, which has been ongoing for several months, involved officers from the National Crime Agency (NCA) and local police forces. In total, around 60 searches were carried out across the country, with the help of the National Crime Agency.

According to the NCA, the website was being used by organized crime groups to commit fraud and steal money from innocent victims. It is not yet clear how much money has been stolen or how many people have been affected.

The arrests come as part of a wider crackdown on cybercrime in the UK. In recent years, there has been a sharp increase in the number of fraud cases involving the internet and digital technology.

The NCA has urged anyone who believes they may have been a victim of fraud to report it to the authorities immediately. It also advised people to take steps to protect their personal information online, such as using strong passwords and two-factor authentication.

The suspects, who have not been named, have been released under investigation while the NCA continues to probe the alleged identity fraud website.

This paper presents PGL, a novel self-supervised learning approach for 3D medical image segmentation. PGL leverages prior knowledge in the form of a pre-trained network to guide local learning, enabling the model to effectively capture complex anatomical structures and improve segmentation performance. Through extensive experiments on two publicly available datasets, we demonstrate the effectiveness of PGL compared to state-of-the-art self-supervised and fully-supervised methods. Our code and models will be made publicly available to facilitate further research in this area.

Sony has announced the latest addition to its PlayStation family, the new PlayStation 3 processor. The new processor, code-named "Cell," is designed to deliver more powerful and realistic gaming experiences to users.

The Cell processor is based on a revolutionary architecture that combines a powerful central processing unit (CPU) with a highly-parallelized system of nine synergistic processors. This unique combination allows the PlayStation 3 to perform complex calculations at lightning-fast speeds, making it possible to render highly-detailed graphics and realistic environments in real-time.

In addition to its powerful processing capabilities, the PlayStation 3 also features a high-speed memory interface and a sophisticated graphics processing unit (GPU). Together, these components work in harmony to deliver a level of gaming performance that is unmatched by any other console on the market today.

Sony has high hopes for the PlayStation 3, which is set to launch later this year. With its advanced processing capabilities and cutting-edge technology, the company believes that the console will set a new standard for gaming and entertainment.

This paper presents a novel approach for joint segmentation and deconvolution of ultrasound images using a hierarchical Bayesian model based on generalized Gaussian priors. The proposed method utilizes a hierarchical model to account for the dependencies between the segmentation and deconvolution tasks, and incorporates generalized Gaussian priors to model the uncertainty in the image degradation process. Experimental results on real ultrasound images demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in improving the segmentation accuracy and resolving the image degradation issue, compared to state-of-the-art methods.

In a stunning upset at the junior boxing championship, 18-year-old Amir Davenport proved why he's been dubbed "the future of British boxing" by dismantling his young rival, 15-year-old Jamie Thompson, in the ring on Saturday.

Davenport, who has been training for years under the watchful eye of his coach, Joe Bloggs, showed no mercy as he dominated the match from start to finish, landing powerful punches and evading Thompson's attempts to counterattack.

Despite being the underdog, Davenport displayed remarkable poise and skill in the ring, leaving spectators and experts alike in awe of his talent. "I knew Amir had the potential to win, but I didn't expect him to dominate like this," said Bloggs, who has been coaching Davenport for five years.

This victory cements Davenport's status as one to watch in the world of boxing, and many are predicting that he will go on to achieve great things in the sport. "Amir has a bright future ahead of him," said Thompson's coach, Sarah Smith. "He's a true talent, and I hope to see him continue to succeed."

As Davenport celebrates his victory, the boxing world waits with bated breath to see what the future holds for this young phenom.

Borders 19-20 Ulster, the largest agricultural show in Ireland, took place last week, attracting thousands of visitors from across the island. The event, which has been running for over 200 years, showcases the best of Irish farming, food, and agriculture.

This year's event featured a range of new attractions, including a drone racing display and a virtual reality experience that allowed visitors to explore the inner workings of a dairy farm. The show also hosted a number of competitions, with farmers vying for top honors in categories such as cattle, sheep, and horses.

Despite concerns about the impact of Brexit on the agricultural industry, the show's organizers reported a successful event, with positive feedback from visitors and exhibitors alike. "We're delighted with how the show has gone this year," said show director Jane Ross. "We've had a great turnout, and the feedback from visitors and exhibitors has been very positive."

Borders 19-20 Ulster is an important event for the Irish agricultural industry, providing a platform for farmers to showcase their products and connect with buyers from around the world. It is also a significant contributor to the local economy, with an estimated 5 million ($6.5 million) generated in revenue each year.

Looking ahead, the show's organizers have announced plans to expand the event in future years, with a focus on sustainability and innovation. "We're always looking for ways to improve the show and stay relevant," said Ross. "Sustainability and innovation are key areas of focus for us, and we're excited to explore new ways of incorporating these themes into the event in the years to come."

The Russian film "The Whistle" has won the prestigious BBC World News Film Prize for its powerful portrayal of corruption and abuse of power in Russia. The film, directed by Kirill Serebrennikov, tells the story of a music teacher who stands up to the corrupt authorities in a small town in Siberia. The jury praised the film for its "brave and timely" message, and for its "stunning" cinematography. The film has been widely acclaimed for its portrayal of the struggles of ordinary people in Russia, and for its bold criticism of the country's political system. The BBC World News Film Prize is one of the most prestigious awards in the film industry, and is awarded to a film that best reflects the values of the BBC, including accuracy, impartiality, and creativity. This is the first time a Russian film has won the award.

This academic paper examines the concept of learning to pay attention to mistakes in the context of cognitive development and error management. The paper explores the role of mistakes in the learning process and how individuals can develop the ability to recognize and learn from their mistakes. The paper also discusses the implications of this concept for education and training, highlighting the importance of creating a supportive learning environment that encourages students to acknowledge and learn from their mistakes. Overall, the paper argues that learning to pay attention to mistakes is a critical skill for personal and professional success, and that educators and trainers should prioritize the development of this skill in their teaching practices.

This academic paper investigates the use of transductive image segmentation, specifically focusing on the effectiveness of self-training and the impact of uncertainty estimation. A report released today has criticized the government's defense spending, claiming that it is not sufficient to protect the country from potential threats. The report, commissioned by a group of independent experts, argues that the current spending levels are inadequate and that the government needs to increase its investment in defense.

The report comes at a time when the government is facing pressure to increase spending on public services, including healthcare and education, which have suffered from years of austerity measures. However, the authors of the report argue that defense spending is essential to protect the country and its citizens.

The report highlights several areas where the government needs to increase spending, including on equipment and technology, personnel, and infrastructure. It also calls for a more comprehensive strategy to address the changing nature of threats, including cyber attacks and terrorism.

The government has responded to the report by stating that it takes the issue of defense spending seriously and that it is committed to ensuring the country's security. However, it has not yet provided a detailed response to the report's recommendations.

The opposition parties have welcomed the report and have called on the government to act on its recommendations. The leader of the opposition has stated that the government must prioritize defense spending and invest in the country's security.

Overall, the report has raised concerns about the government's commitment to defense and has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive strategy to protect the country from potential threats.

This academic paper explores the concept of forming a random field via stochastic cliques, starting from random graphs and eventually leading to fully connected random fields. The paper provides a detailed analysis of the process and its implications in the field of mathematics and computer science. The authors demonstrate how this approach can be used to generate random fields with specific properties, making it a valuable tool for various applications. Overall, the paper offers a novel perspective on the generation of random fields and its potential applications.

The European Commission has given the green light to the construction of a controversial oil pipeline that will run through the Balkans. The pipeline, which has faced opposition from environmental groups and some countries in the region, will connect the Caspian Sea with the Adriatic Sea and is expected to transport up to 50 million tons of oil per year.

The pipeline, known as the Southern Corridor, has been in the works for several years and is seen as an alternative to the Russian-dominated Northern Corridor. It will pass through Bulgaria, Serbia, Hungary, and Croatia, with the Commission giving its approval after the project's sponsors agreed to take measures to protect the environment and comply with EU regulations.

However, some countries in the region, including Greece and Slovenia, have expressed concerns about the potential impact on the environment and have called for more stringent safety measures. Opponents of the pipeline have also raised concerns about its potential to exacerbate conflicts in the region and increase dependence on imported oil.

Despite these concerns, the Commission has stressed the importance of the pipeline in ensuring the security of energy supplies in Europe and promoting economic growth in the region. The pipeline is expected to create thousands of jobs and generate billions of euros in revenue for the countries it passes through.

Construction of the pipeline is expected to begin later this year, with the first phase of the project due to be completed by 2025.

Leaders from the European Union gathered on Friday to discuss Turkey's bid to join the bloc, amid concerns over the country's human rights record and political instability.

The meeting comes as Turkey faces a growing refugee crisis, with thousands of people fleeing the conflict in Syria and seeking refuge in the country. EU leaders are expected to press Turkey to do more to help manage the flow of migrants and to address concerns over its treatment of political opponents and journalists.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is expected to make the case for his country's EU membership, arguing that it would help stabilize the region and provide a buffer against the spread of extremism.

However, some EU leaders have expressed skepticism about Turkey's readiness for EU membership, citing concerns over its democratic standards and the rule of law.

The meeting is expected to set the stage for further negotiations between Turkey and the EU, with a decision on whether to open new chapters in the accession talks expected to be delayed until a later date.

This paper investigates the shape bifurcation of a spherical dielectric elastomer balloon under the actions of internal pressure and electric voltage. The study employs a mathematical model to analyze the deformation and stress distribution of the balloon at different levels of pressure and voltage. The results reveal that the balloon undergoes a transition from a spherical shape to an ellipsoidal shape as the pressure and voltage are increased. The paper concludes by discussing the implications of these findings for the design and application of dielectric elastomer devices in various fields, such as soft robotics, medical devices, and sensors.

This paper presents a comparative study of droplet impact near a millimetre-sized hole, examining the behavior of droplets in a closed pit and an open-ended pore. The study employs high-speed imaging and pressure measurements to analyze the impact dynamics and the resulting splatter patterns. The results reveal that the presence of an open-ended pore significantly reduces the splatter area and pressure, while the closed pit leads to a higher splatter area and pressure. The findings suggest that the open-ended pore can be utilized to minimize droplet impact-induced contamination in microfluidic devices and other applications.

This academic paper explores the mathematical concept of snow leopard permutations and their even and odd threads. Snow leopard permutations are a type of permutation that satisfies certain conditions, and their even and odd threads are important features of these permutations. The paper provides a detailed analysis of these permutations and their threads, including their properties, relationships, and applications in various fields. The paper concludes by discussing the potential future research directions in this area.

This paper explores the concept of p-adic differential equations with separation of variables, providing a detailed analysis of their properties and solutions. The authors utilize advanced mathematical techniques to derive novel results and offer insights into the potential applications of these equations in various fields, including physics and engineering. Overall, this paper offers a valuable contribution to the existing literature on p-adic analysis and differential equations, highlighting the importance of these topics in modern mathematics and science.
